title: Why Focus on Cervical Cancer
description: Learn the global, regional, and local impact of cervical cancer and why it matters.

sections.title: Reasons to Focus on Cervical Cancer
sections.description: Why cervical cancer is a global health priority.

learningCards.title: Global Statistics
learningCards.content: Every year, around 266,000 women die from cervical cancer worldwide. Most of these deaths can be prevented.

learningCards.title: HPV and Disease Timeline
learningCards.content: Almost all cervical cancer is caused by long-lasting infection with HPV. The disease usually develops over 10–20 years.

learningCards.title: Vaccination and Prevention
learningCards.content: There are low-cost tests that detect pre-cancer early, and HPV vaccines can prevent most cervical cancer if given early.

sections.title: Epidemiology of Cervical Cancer
sections.description: Understanding the global and African burden of the disease.

learningCards.title: Global Burden
learningCards.content: Cervical cancer is the 4th most common cancer in women, with 660,000 new cases and 350,000 deaths in 2022.

learningCards.title: Africa's Burden
learningCards.content: Africa has the highest rates of cervical cancer and deaths, with low access to screening and vaccines.

learningCards.title: Ghana’s Burden
learningCards.content: Ghana sees about 29.3 cases per 100,000 women annually, with high mortality due to low screening and cultural beliefs.

sections.title: Female Pelvic Anatomy and Physiology
sections.description: Learn about internal and external female reproductive anatomy.

learningCards.title: External Organs
learningCards.content: Includes the vulva, labia, clitoris, urethra, perineum, and Bartholin glands.

learningCards.title: Internal Organs
learningCards.content: Includes the uterus, bladder, ureters, and how they function in reproduction.

learningCards.title: Diagnostic Tools
learningCards.content: These organs are examined using a speculum or laparoscopy to detect abnormalities.
